The number of  full-size sheet pans a full-size convection oven can accommodate.
The measured amount of time an oven requires to pre-heat in convection mode.
The approach used for all ovens to generate steam while operating in steam mode (e.g. boiler/steam generator, boilerless, or spritzer/injector).

Designates type of commercial oven model in simple terms as one of the following: electric convection oven, gas convection oven, electric combination oven, gas combination oven, gas single rack oven, or gas double rack oven.
The rack oven has a default setback mode during extended periods of non-use where the oven is idling at a reduced temperature set point.
The measured amount of energy an electric oven in steam mode consumes during the pre-heat test.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

The baking-energy efficiency production capacity of a rack oven operating in baking mode is expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the oven brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).

Designates the size of the commercial convection and combination oven model (but not gas rack ovens), according to the following options for Version 3.0: 1) Full-size convection oven (a convection oven that is able to accomodate standard full-size sheet pans measuring 18 x 26 x 1-inch); 2) Half-size convection oven (a convection oven that is able to accomodate half-sheet pans measuring 18 x 13 x 1-inch); 3) Full-size combination ovens (a combination oven that is able to accomodate two GN 1/1 steam pans measuring 20 3/4 x 12 3/4-inch, per rack or tray position); 4) Half-size combination ovens (a combination oven that is able to accomodate a one GN 1/1 steam pan measuring 20 3/4 x 12 3/4-inch, per rack or tray position); and two-third-size combination ovens (a combination oven that is able to accomodate one GN 2/3 steam pan measuring 13 3/4 x 12 3/4-inch, per rack or tray position). The Version 3.0 specification covers full-size and half-size electric convection ovens; full-size gas convection ovens; full- and half-size electric and gas combination ovens; two-third-size combination ovens.
The measured amount of energy a gas oven in convection mode consumes during the pre-heat test.
The average water consumption rate of a combination oven operating in steam mode during idle periods expressed in gallons per hour per pan.
The average water consumption rate of a combination oven operating in steam mode during cooking periods expressed in gallons per pan.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
For gas ovens with variable Btu/h input, each available input shall be tested individually and meet the cooking energy efficiency and idle energy rate requirements of the specification.

The average rate of auxillary electric energy consumed (i.e., fan motor, lighting, controls, etc.) in Watts by the gas convection oven or combination oven operating in convection mode while idling at a ready-to-cook temperature set point.

For ovens with variable Btu/h input, each available input shall be tested individually and meet the cooking energy efficiency and idle energy rate requirements of the specification. The calculated gas or electric oven convection mode idle energy rate value.
The average rate of energy consumed in Btu/h by the gas  combination oven operating in steam mode while idling at a ready-to-cook temperature set point.

The cooking-energy efficiency percentage for an oven operating in convection mode is the quantity of energy input to the food product (i.e., potatoes) during the cooking process; expressed as a percentage of the quantity of energy input to the oven during the cooking-energy efficiency tests.

The cooking-energy efficiency percentage for a combination oven operating in steam mode is the quantity of energy input to the food product (i.e., potatoes) during the cooking process; expressed as a percentage of the quantity of energy input to the oven during the cooking-energy efficiency tests.

The cooking-energy efficiency production capacity of a combination oven operating in steam mode is expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the oven brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Light Commercial HVAC
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 4.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Light Commercial HVAC that are effective as of January 1, 2023. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/heating_cooling/light_commercial_heating_cooling/key_product_criteria.
columns_description: An air conditioner model consists of one or more factory-made assemblies that normally include an evaporator or cooling coil(s), compressor(s), and condenser(s) to provide the function of air cooling. A heat pump model is similar but also provides the function of air heating. Air conditioners and heat pumps may additionally include the functions of air circulation, air cleaning, dehumidifying, or humidifying. A variable refrigerant flow multi-split (VRF) model consists of a unit of commercial package air-conditioning and heating equipment that is configured as a split system incorporating a single refrigerant circuit, with one or more outdoor units, at least one variable-speed compressor or an alternate compressor combination for varying the capacity of the system by three or more steps, and multiple indoor fan coil units, each of which is individually metered and individually controlled by an integral control device and common communications network and which can operate independently in response to multiple indoor thermostats. Very Small: <65,000 BTU/h Small: ≥65,000 BTU/h and <135,000 BTU/h Large: ≥135,000 BTU/h and <240,000 BTU/h

This column identifies whether the system uses a split system arrangement (remote condensing unit) or a single package system (all components are stored in a single cabinet). All VRF models are required to be listed as "Split System".
A measure of efficiency in the heating mode that represents the ratio of total heating capacity to electrical energy input, measured at 47 degrees F.

The ratio of the total heat removed from the conditioned space during the annual cooling season to the total electrical energy consumed by the air conditioner or heat pump during the same season, expressed in Btu/Wh using Proposed Appendix B1 at 86 FR 70316, 70346-70347 (Dec. 9, 2021).

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

The total heating output of a central air-conditioning heat pump during its normal annual usage period for heating, expressed in Btu's and divided by the total electric power input, expressed in Btu/Wh using 10 CFR part 431, Subpart F, §431.96, Table 1.
The ability of the system to deliver sensible and latent heating when the outside air temperature is 47 F.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit. For light commercial HVAC models, model number indicates the outdoor model number.

IEER is a measure that expresses cooling part-load EER efficiency for commercial air-conditioners, heat pumps, and VRF Multi-Splits on the basis of weighted operation at various load capacities using 10 CFR part 431, Subpart F, §431.96, Table 1.
A measure of efficiency in the heating mode that represents the ratio of total heating capacity to electrical energy input, measured at 5 degrees F.
The ratio of the produced cooling effect of an air conditioner or heat pump to its net work input, expressed in Btu/watt-hour using 10 CFR part 431, Subpart F, §431.96, Table 1.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

The ratio of the total heat removed from the conditioned space during the annual cooling season to the total electrical energy consumed by the air conditioner or heat pump during the same season, expressed in Btu/Wh using 10 CFR part 431, Subpart F, §431.96, Table 1.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
A measure of efficiency in the heating mode that represents the ratio of total heating capacity to electrical energy input, measured at 17 degrees F.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

The type of heating section the LCHVAC systems uses. Central air conditioners and heat pumps systems can use either all other heating section types (propane, gas, oil), electric resistance, or none. VRF Multi-Split systems either come with heat recovery or without heat recovery.
The ratio of the produced cooling effect of an air conditioner or heat pump to its net work input, expressed in Btu/watt-hour using Proposed Appendix B1 at 86 FR 70316, 70346-70347 (Dec. 9, 2021).

The capacity associated with the change in air enthalpy between the air entering the unit and the air leaving the unit, which includes both the latent (change in humidity ratio) and sensible (change in dry-bulb temperature) capacities expressed in Btu/h and include the heat of circulation fan(s) and motor(s).
The ability of the system to deliver sensible and latent heating when the outside air temperature is 5 F.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Meets EER2 requirements for efficient cooling at 95F.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for light commercial HVAC include R-32 and R-454B.
The ability of the system to deliver sensible and latent heating when the outside air temperature is 17 F.

The total heating output of a central air-conditioning heat pump during its normal annual usage period for heating, expressed in Btu's and divided by the total electric power input, expressed in Btu/Wh using Proposed Appendix B1 at 86 FR 70316, 70346-70347 (Dec. 9, 2021).

Indicates heat pumps that meet the ENERGY STAR cold climate criteria; cold climate heat pumps will provide better heating performance in low ambient temperatures, making these products an excellent choice for cold climate installations where the heat pump will be the sole heating source.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Light Bulbs
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 2.0 and V2.1 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Lamps (Light Bulbs) that are effective as of January 2, 2017. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/lighting_fans/light_bulbs/key_product_criteria
columns_description: A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
The maximum diameter of the light bulb in millimeters.
A description of the reported light output, measured in lumens (not watts). To save energy, find the ENERGY STAR bulbs with the lumens you need, then choose the one with the lowest watts.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The number of years the light bulb is covered under the manufacturer’s warranty.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

The Color Rendering Index (CRI) of a light source is a measure of color quality and represents the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature. The ENERGY STAR specifications require a CRI of at least 80. Incandescent lighting has a CRI of 100. Early fluorescent lighting had CRIs in the 60s, resulting in unpleasant appearance of skin tones.
The electric power a light bulb needs to operate is designated by watts (W). For more information, visit our web page on this topic: http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=cfls.pr_cfls_lumens
Center beam candle power (CBCP) the luminous intensity at the center of the beam, measured in candela (cd).
The maximum length of the light bulb in millimeters.
The minimum light output level of a lamp when operated on a dimmer. Typically expressed as a percentage.

The shape of the light bulb. General purpose incandescent (i.e. 40W, 60W etc.) replacements include bare-spiral CFLs, and A-shape CFLs and LED bulbs. Globe or "G" type shapes are common for bathroom vanity lights, Reflector bulbs are commonly referred to as flood or spot lights and include R (reflector), bulged reflector (BR), parabolic aluminum reflector (PAR), multifaceted reflector (MR), etc. Decorative types include candle (C) shapes, and Other includes non-standard and less common CFL and LED shapes, etc.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
Indicates whether the lamp meets the criteria to be recognized as connected.
Whether the lamp is rated for use in enclosed fixtures.
The technology of the light bulb e.g. compact fluorescent light bulbs (CFL) or light emitting diode (LED).
Indicates if the lamp is capable of three way operation.
The method of communications or connected protocol that a connected lamp uses.
The reported angle of the light distribution at which the luminous intensity is 1/2 of the center beam (in degrees).

A light bulb’s estimated lifetime in hours determined by operating a sample of bulbs according to industry test standards. For traditional bulbs like incandescent and CFLs the time that half of the test sample fails is considered rated life. For LED lighting the life is based on the estimated time for the product’s light output to decrease light 30%. By definition, some lamps will fail before their rated life and some will operate beyond their rated life. The ENERGY STAR specifications set minimum rated lifetimes and require extensive switching and long term testing to stress the products. Actual lifetime of products will vary depending on use.

The ratio of real power that flows to the light bulb versus the amount of power actually consumed. A light bulb with a lower power factor will draw more current than a light bulb with a higher power factor for the same amount of useful power transferred.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

The shape of the light bulb. General purpose incandescent (i.e. 40W, 60W etc.) replacements include bare-spiral CFLs, and A-shape CFLs and LED bulbs. Globe or "G" type shapes are common for bathroom vanity lights, Reflector bulbs are commonly referred to as flood or spot lights and include R (reflector), bulged reflector (BR), parabolic aluminum reflector (PAR), multifaceted reflector (MR), etc. Decorative types include candle (C) shapes, and Other includes non-standard and less common CFL and LED shapes, etc.

The appearance of the light is indicated by the Correlated Color Temperature (CCT) on the Kelvin scale. Lower Kelvin numbers like 2700-3000K mean the light appears more “warm” like incandescent; a CCT of 3500-4100K mean the light is whiter and higher temperatures like 5000-6500K would appear slightly bluer. Light appearance is indicated on bulb packaging.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The familiar wattage of the traditional bulb that this efficient bulb can replace using fewer watts.

Most bulbs are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some bulbs have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers or three-way control. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product.
The amount of power that a connected lamp draws when it is not producing light but in standby mode.
The connector at the bottom of the light bulb: Common base types include the “Edison” or “medium” screw base (E26), candelabra screw base (E12), and multiple pin bases (GU24, GU10) etc.

The R9 value is not included in the Color Rendering Index (CRI) score but important for a light source to show red in objects with red in them, such as skin tones, natural wood tones, produce, meats, and artwork. Higher numbers represent more accurate rendering of red.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Indicates the nominal purpose of the lamp, omnidirectional or general purpose, directional, or decorative.
Indicates if the lamp manufacturer claims that the lamp is dimmable and meets the requirements in the specification.
The measure of efficiency of a lamp, defined as the quotient of the total luminous flux emitted by the total light source power input.

The condition where the product is connected to a power source, produces neither sound nor picture, neither transmits nor receives program information and/or data (excluding data transmitted to change the unit's condition from Sleep Mode to On Mode), and is waiting to be switched to On Mode by a direct or indirect signal from the consumer (e.g., with the remote control).

For ac minimum configuration models, the  calculated efficiency expressed as a decimal based on measured test data at the following loads: 25%, 50%, 75%, 100%. For multiple-normal-mode UPSs, the efficiency in the highest dependency is also reported.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of

The actual power supplied to the maximum load for which the maximum configuration model is designed or rated to support.

The capability of an Ac-output UPS to operate in one or more Normal Modes classified by input dependency characteristic (ordered from highest to lowest input dependency): Voltage and Frequency Dependent (VFD): Capable of protecting the load from power outage Voltage Independent (VI): Capable of protecting the load as required for VFD, above, and in addition from under-voltage applied continuously to the input and over-voltage applied continuously to the input Voltage and Frequency Independent (VFI): Independent of voltage and frequency variations and capable of protecting the load against adverse effects from such variation without depleting the stored energy source. Input dependency characteristic is not applicable to Dc-output UPS/Rectifier models.

For ac maximum configuration models, the  calculated efficiency expressed as a decimal based on measured test data at the following loads: 25%, 50%, 75%, 100%. For multiple-normal-mode UPSs, the efficiency in the highest dependency is also reported.

The calculated average efficiency of the maximum configuration Multiple-normal-mode Ac-output UPS model operating in the highest-input dependency normal mode (i.e., VFI or VI) at specified percentages of the rated load. The average efficiency is weighted to reflect the expected utilization of the UPS. 

This column does not apply to Dc-output UPSs which are tested in a single mode only.
Indicates the total number of surge protected only outlets provided by the model.
The physical depth of the model in millimeters, not including any external energy storage system with separate enclosures.

Indicates the intended application(s) for the model. Consumer models are intended to protect desktop computers and related peripherals, and/or home entertainment devices such as TVs, set-top boxes, DVRs, Blu-ray and DVD players. Commercial models are intended to protect small business and branch office information and communication technology equipment such as servers, network switches and routers, and small storage arrays. Data Center models are intended to protect large installations of information and communication technology equipment such as enterprise servers, networking equipment, and large storage arrays.

The model number of the specific tested single configuration model of a non-Modular UPS or the minimum configuration model of a Modular UPS.  A Modular UPS is comprised of two or more single UPS modules, sharing one or more common frames and a common energy storage system, whose outputs, in normal mode of operation, are connected to a common output bus contained entirely within the frame(s). Modular UPSs may be used to provide redundancy, to scale capacity or both. For qualification of a Modular UPS Product Family, both the minimum and maximum configuration models are tested.

Single-normal-mode UPS: A UPS that functions in Normal Mode within the parameters of only one set of input dependency characteristics. For example, a UPS that functions only as VFI.
Multiple-normal-mode UPS: A UPS that functions in Normal Mode within the parameters of more than one set of input dependency characteristics. For example, a UPS that can function as either VFI or VFD.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Vending Machines
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 4.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Refrigerated Beverage Vending Machines that are effective as of April 29, 2020.  A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/other/vending_machines/key_product_criteria.

columns_description: Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

Refrigerated beverage vending machines are either Class A or Class B. Combination vending machines are either Combination A or Combination B. 'A' types have mostly transparent fronts; 'B' types have mostly opaque fronts. Combination machines may contain two or more compartments separated by a solid partition. For detailed definitions see the RBVM product specification.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The daily energy consumption value in kWh per day.
For rebuilt machines, the OEM of the energy efficiency component(s)/kit installed to meet ENERGY STAR requirements.

For rebuilt machines, the component type(s) used in the energy efficiency kit or as represented by the Component Model Numbers (e.g., fan assembly).

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
Indicates which low power modes are supported by the product.

Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The type of refrigerant used by the product.
Refrigerated volume represents the volume of the interior cabinet where cold beverages are stored as measured by 10 CFR Part 431 Subpart Q, Appendix B.
For rebuilt machines, a distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the OEM.
For rebuilt machines, the model number of the energy efficiency component(s)/kit installed to meet ENERGY STAR requirements.
Indoor/outdoor machines may be suitable for outdoor use or suitable for protected locations. Indoor machines are suitable for indoor use only (per UL Standard 541).
For rebuilt machines, name of the company that originally built the machine. This may or may not be the same organization that upgrades the machine to meet ENERGY STAR requirements.

The maximum quantity of standard product that can be dispensed from one full loading of the vending machine without further reload operations when used as recommended by the manufacturer (per ANSI/ASHRAE 32.1).
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
For rebuilt machines, an identifier assigned by the OEM to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
For models with an Accessory Low Power Mode, the accessories which are equipped with a low power mode.
Vending machines eligible for ENERGY STAR may have a closed front door, glass front door, or live display front door.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for vending machines include R-290, R-600a, and R-744 (CO₂).
A 'Yes' in this column indicates that the model is a rebuilt machine. The model was previously in use and subject to retrofitting or refurbishing for resale

The power state in which the operating system and other software have completed loading, a user profile has been created, activity is limited to those basic applications that the system starts by default, and the computer is not in Sleep Mode. Furthermore, the Computer has reached an Idle condition, but the Display is on, and Long Idle power management features have not engaged.
Display Sleep Mode shall be set to activate after no more than 15 minutes of user inactivity.

Desktop: A computer whose main unit is designed to be located in a permanent location, often on a desk or on the floor. Desktop computers are not designed for portability and are designed for use with an external display, keyboard, and mouse.

Integrated Computer: A desktop computer in which the computing hardware and display are integrated into a single housing, and which is connected to ac mains power through a single cable. Integrated desktop computers come in one of two possible forms: (1) a system where the display and computer are physically combined into a single unit; or (2) a system packaged as a single system where the display is separate but is connected to the main chassis by a dc power cord and both the computer and display are powered from a single power supply.

Notebook: A computer designed specifically for portability and to be operated for extended periods of time both with and without a direct connection to an ac mains power source.

Slate/tablet: A computing device designed for portability.

Portable All-in-one Computer: A computing device designed for limited portability.

Small-scale Server: A computer that typically uses desktop components in a desktop form factor, but is designed primarily to be a storage host for other computers. Small-scale Servers are designed to perform functions such as providing network infrastructure services (e.g., archiving) and hosting data/media.

Thin Client: An independently-powered computer that relies on a connection to remote computing resources to obtain primary functionality. Main computing functions (e.g., program execution, data storage, interaction with other Internet resources) are provided by the remote computing resources.

Workstation: A high-performance, single-user computer typically used for graphics, CAD, software development, financial and scientific applications among other compute intensive tasks.

The Dust-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate per Watt or Dust CADR/W is the energy efficiency metric for room air cleaners. More efficient units have higher Dust CADR/W.
The Smoke-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate per Watt or Smoke CADR/W is the energy efficiency metric for room air cleaners. More efficient units have higher Smoke CADR/W.
The Pollen-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate per Watt or Pollen CADR/W is the energy efficiency metric for room air cleaners. More efficient units have higher Pollen CADR/W.
The Rated Dust-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate or Dust CADR is the manufacturer-reported delivery of dust-free air produced by a household electric, cord-connected room air cleaner.

Room size in square feet is calculated by multiplying the Smoke CADR by 1.55 or by 0.144 for square meters. This room size formula is based on the CADR requirement to remove 80% of smoke particles, assuming one room air exchange per hour.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
The average power in partial on mode, measured in Watts. Partial on mode includes standby and network connected power.
The Rated Pollen-Free Clean Air Delivery Rate or Pollen CADR is the manufacturer-reported delivery of pollen-free air produced by a household electric, cord-connected room air cleaner.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the room air cleaner under typical conditions, including the energy used in active modes and partial on modes. It is calculated by multiplying the active mode hours by the smoke CADR divided by the smoke CADR/W and added to the inactive model hours multiplied by the partial on mode power. The active mode hours are assumed to be 5,840 hours per year and 2,920 for inactive mode hours, which is on average 16 hours active and 8 hours inactive per day. Actual energy consumption will vary depending on various factors such as the amount of usage in active mode and the settings chosen.
Indicates the air cleaning technologies used by the room air cleaner, such as, fan and filter, fan with electrostatic plates, ion generator, and other technologies.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
The ozone emissions, measured in parts per billion.

Indicates the primary type of filter, if the air cleaner has a filter. High-Efficiency Particulate Air filters or HEPA filters sometimes, also called True HEPA filters, have a minimum fractional particle removal efficiency of 99.97% for all particles of 0.3 μm diameter. Filters described as HEPA-Type or something other than “HEPA” or “True HEPA” have not demonstrated they meet the HEPA standard. Consumers should look to the product literature for documentation of the efficacy of these filters.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a replacement filter by the manufacturer.

Indicates the secondary type of filter, if the air cleaner has more than one filter. Consumers should look to the product literature for documentation of the efficacy of these filters.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a replacement filter by the manufacturer.

columns_description: Portable dehumidifiers operate within the dehumidified space without the attachment of additional ducting. Whole-home dehumidifiers are installed with ducting to deliver return process air to the inlet and to supply dehumidified process air from the outlet to one or more locations in the dehumidified space. Some dehumidifiers can operate in both configurations by means of a ducting kit.

Some dehumidifiers can operate in an alternate configuration (e.g., a whole-home can operate as a portable) depending on how it is installed. This column indicates the efficiency of the dehumidifier in the configuration opposite of that listed under "Dehumidifier Type". If nothing is listed, the dehumidifier cannot operate in an alternate configuration.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

Some dehumidifiers can operate in an alternate configuration (e.g., a whole-home can operate as a portable) depending on how it is installed. This column indicates the  water removal capacity of the dehumidifier in the configuration opposite of that listed under "Dehumidifier Type". If nothing is listed, the dehumidifier cannot operate in an alternate configuration.
For whole-home dehumidifiers, this is a measure of the rectangular volume that the product case occupies, exclusive of any duct attachment collars or other external components.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

A measure of a dehumidifier's ability to remove moisture from its surrounding atmosphere, measured in pints collected per 24 hours, based on DOE's Appendix X1 test method. This represents the expected performance in a basement for portable dehumidifiers and expected performance in the average home for whole-home dehumidifiers.

Some dehumidifiers can operate in both the portable and whole-home configurations by means of a ducting kit. For a dehumidifier sold as a whole-home type that can also operate as a portable type, the portable configuration is listed here as the alternate, and vice versa.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
A measure of energy efficiency of a dehumidifier that encompasses dehumidification mode and non-dehumidification mode energy consumption.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Ice Machines
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Automatic Commercial Ice Makers that are effective as of January 28, 2018 . A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria is available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/commercial_food_service_equipment/commercial_ice_makers/key_product_criteria
columns_description: Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as load shifting, ice level sensor and Demand Response exit points. Commercial ice machines with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering electric bills.
This summarizes the connected functionality capabilities if the model has connected functionality.
Indicates the refrigerant type used.
The gross weight of ice harvested, stated in lb/24 h [kg/24 h], stated in multiples of 1.

If the product type is RCU, this field provides the model number of the remote condenser unit that is to accompany the ice-making mechanism (i.e., what condenser the unit was tested with and qualifies for ENERGY STAR under).
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for commercial ice machines include R-290, R-450A, and R-513A.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

The total energy input rate, stated in kWh/100 lb [kWh/45.0 kg] of ice. For continuous type commercial ice makers this reflects the measured energy consumption per 100 lbs ice, multiplied by the ice hardness adjustment factor. (For batch type commercial ice makers the ice hardness is assumed to be 100%, therefore no adjustment is needed.) For RCU (with remote compressor), total energy consumed shall include the energy use of the ice-making mechanism, the compressor and the remote condensing unit.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The net cooling effect of ice harvested (Btu/lb) divided by 144 (Btu/lb), expressed as a percent. The Ice Hardness Factor for batch type machines is assumed to be 100%, but must be tested and reported for continuous type machine certification. (For certain models this may exceed 100%.)
The type of ice the ice maker produces. Options include batch-type (which include cube type ice and other batch technologies) and continuous-type (which include flake and nugget ice types).

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

The amount of potable water used in making ice, which is equal to the sum of the ice harvested, Dump or Purge Water, and the Harvest Water expressed in gal/100 lb [L/45.0 kg] of ice, stated in multiples of 0.1. Alternatively, the amount of water entering the ice maker per cycle can be measured.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

Connected products may or may not enable open-standards connectivity. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" A product that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" A product that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Provides guidance about what is needed to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.

The type of equipment category the ice maker falls into. The three categories include Ice Making Head (IMH), Remote Condensing Unit (RCU) with remote compressor, Remote Condensing Unit (RCU) without remote compressor, and Self-Contained Unit (SCU).
Open Standard - Application Layer include SEP 1.x, SEP2.x, OpenADR, etc.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Griddles
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 1.2 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Commercial Griddles that are effective as of May 8, 2009 or January 1, 2011. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/commercial_food_service_equipment/commercial_griddles/key_products_criteria.
columns_description: This column designates whether the model was tested in the single-sided or double-sided configuration.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

The maximum production rate of the griddle while cooking a specified food product in accordance with the heavy-load cooking-energy efficiency test, expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the griddle brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

For gas griddles, this field expresses the rate of  griddle energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at a stabilized operating condition or temperature. The idle rate is normalized based on the area of the (bottom) cooking surface.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Represents the surface area of the commercial griddle (width multiplied by the depth).
This field provides additional details as to the type of griddle plate used (e.g., polished steel or chrome ½-inch grooved plate).
The ratio of energy absorbed by the food product to the total energy supplied to the griddle during cooking.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
This field demonstrates whether the product has integrated or add-on top platens. This impacts the testing of the models as single- or double-sided.

For electric griddles, this field expresses the rate of  griddle energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at a stabilized operating condition or temperature. The idle rate is normalized based on the area of the (bottom) cooking surface.

Designates whether the model is a single-sided or double-sided commercial griddle. A double-sided griddle has hinged upper griddle plates (platens) that swing down over the food, thereby cooking the food from both sides at once.
Designates the fuel type used by the commercial griddle. Qualified commercial griddle models are either gas or electric.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

Designates the width of the griddle in ft. For qualification of a product family, the 3 ft. model within the product family can serve as the representative model. (If product family includes units smaller than 3 ft.; however, each additional unit shall be tested and qualified separately from its product family.)
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
Designates the depth of the griddle in ft.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Residential Refrigerators
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 5.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Residential Refrigerators and Freezers that are effective as of September 15, 2014 or the Version 5.1 Program Requirements that are effective as of August 5, 2021. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/appliances/refrigerators/key_product_criteria
columns_name: Percent Less Energy Use than US Federal Standard
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2024 Criteria
columns_description: An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The U.S. federal standard is the maximum energy consumption in kWh/year allowed by the U.S. Department of Energy for a refrigerator or cooler of this particular configuration and size.

This is a figure accounting for the fact that freezers require more energy than refrigerators per unit of actual volume, because they are colder. The adjusted volume is the sum of the fresh food compartment volume, the cooler compartment volume, and the product of an adjustment factor and the net freezer compartment volume in cubic feet. It is used to determine the federal energy conservation standards for refrigerators, freezers, and coolers. Adjusted Volume = Fresh Food Volume + Cooler Volume + (1.76 x Freezer Volume).
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.
ENERGY STAR certified refrigerators and coolers must generally exceed the U.S. federal standard by at least 10%. This column tells you by how much each model exceeds the standard.

This number is the estimated annual energy use in kWh/year of the refrigerator or cooler under typical conditions. Your actual energy consumption will vary depending on how you use your refrigerator or cooler, such as frequency of opening and closing, surrounding room temperature, and how full the unit is kept. This figure is calculated according to U.S. Department of Energy test procedures.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

Refrigerator models listed with Connected Functionality must be tested using the ENERGY STAR Test Method to Validate Demand Response to verify the model’s Demand Response (DR) Functionality. Coolers are not required to be tested.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The total interior volume of the refrigerator, including both the refrigerator and freezer compartments. Generally, the larger the refrigerator, the greater the energy consumption.
Classification of products by the type of energy used or by capacity or other performance-related features that affect efficiency. Different ENERGY STAR levels may apply to different product classes.
Measured from side to side.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
Measured from the floor to top of hinge.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
This refrigerator or cooler design is approximately 24 inches deep without the door, making them nearly flush with standard kitchen cabinets. With the doors, they are generally 27-29 inches deep.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for residential refrigerators include R-600a and R-441A.
This shows the configuration of the refrigerator or cooler.
Included in some refrigerators for making ice cubes.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the refrigerator or cooler door is not closed or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Refrigerators or coolers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
Built-in refrigerators are designed to be installed totally encased by kitchen cabinets.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Open Standard - Application Layer include SEP 1.x, SEP2.x, OpenADR, etc.
Designation for refrigerators, refrigerator-freezers, and coolers with a total volume of less than 7.75 cubic feet and 36 inches or less in height.
Allows access to ice and/or water through an exterior dispenser. Automatic icemakers and through the door dispensers offer convenience but they can increase energy use by 14-20%.
This is the type of defrost function. Automatic, manual, and partial automatic are the standard defrost types.

Standard HPWH require 240 Volt service, but certain products are appropriate for installation on a 120 Volt, 15 Amp Circuit. Split-System heat pump water heaters are residential water heaters where the compressor, evaporator, and/or condenser are separated from the storage tank.
The limit to the system’s tolerance of freezing weather conditions.
The minimum amount of hot water, in gallons, a tankless water heater can supply per minute over a 67°F rise.
System can communicate using these protocols for sending messages and requests, some of which work wirelessly and some with wires (open standard media/network layer).
Tank diameter is the width or diameter of the water heater’s tank.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Volume is the capacity of the tank, in gallons. Storage Volume is not applicable for gas tankless, solar with gas backup, or solar with electric backup water heaters.
Gallons/year refers to the amount of propane consumed by the water heater with a tested outlet temperature of 125°F.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.

Solar Water Heaters are available in the following collector types: batch, flat-plate, and evacuated tube. Batch collectors heat water in dark tanks or tubes within an insulated box, storing the water until drawn. Flat-plate collectors consist of copper tubes fitted to flat absorber plates. Evacuated tubes contain a vacuum of space around the metal or glass tube.
The water heater's depth, in inches.
Sound pressure level as measured per the NEEA Electric or Gas-Fueled Advanced Water Heating Specification, in dBA
Requested if Product Type is Heat Pump. Include the ambient temperature above which the compressor cuts off and electric resistance only operation begins.
Tank height is the distance from the bottom of the water heater’s tank to the top of its tank.

Forced Circulation systems use a pump to circulate the water or other fluid from the collector where it is heated by the sun to the storage tank. Integral Collector Storage (ICS) systems, or “batch” water heaters, combine the collector and the storage tank into one. Thermosyphon systems have a separate storage tank, located above the collector. Liquid (which could be water or an antifreeze solution) warmed in the collector rises to the storage tank.
Indicates product model is eligible for federal income tax credits available under the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Electric usage per year per

Solar Uniform Energy Factor (SUEF) refers to the energy delivered by the total system divided by the electrical or gas energy put into the system. A value of 99 indicates that under rating conditions, the system used no gas or electrical energy to heat water.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
Refers to the total area consumed by the solar collector.
Capacity of the tank, in gallons.
The Hardware Architecture describes the type of module/device within or external to the system needed for connection.
Indicates which standardized protocol is used to send load management messages to the unit.

Vent size 2 is the width or diameter of a second vent opening.
Recovery efficiency refers to how efficiently the heat from the burner is transferred to the water in the tank.
Maximum amperage

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Heat pump water heaters require refrigerants as well. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for heat pump water heaters include R-744 (CO₂).

Uniform Energy Factor (UEF) is the newest measure of water heater overall efficiency. It is a metric used to compare the relative efficiencies of water heaters. The higher the UEF is, the more efficient the water heater.
The maximum amount of hot water, in gallons, a tankless water heater can supply per minute over a 67°F rise.
Fuel type refers the kind of fuel the water heater uses to heat the water, either natural gas or propane.
Height to vent is the distance from the bottom of the water heater’s tank to its vent.

The OG-300 certification number is assigned by the Solar Rating & Certification Corporation.
The rate at which energy is consumed by the gas water heater when running at maximum capacity, in BTU/hr.

Draw pattern used per the Appendix E test method. For storage-type water heaters, draw pattern is determined by the FHR test. For gas tankless water heaters, draw pattern is determined per Max. GPM rating test. For all solar water heaters,  draw pattern is determined by collector size.
First Hour Rating is the amount of hot water (in gallons) a storage water heater can supply in the first hour of using water, starting with a tank full of hot water.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. Describes whether the product can participate in utility demand response programs without the home having a broadband connection.

Indicates if a product is capable of responding to Set Point Adjustment and/or Relative Price Signal commands.
Voltage required for a heat pump water heater.

A Television is a product designed to produce dynamic video. A TV contains an internal TV tuner

A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/commercial_food_service_equipment/commercial_dishwashers/key_product_criteria.

columns_description: Describes if the dishwasher has a booster heater that is inseparable.  A booster heater is a water heater that raises the temperature of preheated water 40 to 80°F. The preheated water is supplied to the unit [booster heater] at temperatures that are typically between100 and 140°F. This booster heater can be either integral to the dishwasher, or externally connected. The booster heater (internal or external) energy consumption shall be measured and reported separately, if possible. However, if booster energy cannot be measured separately it will be included in the idle energy rate measurements.

"Warewashing equipment with heat recovery; a heat exchanger that recovers energy from other heat sources (i.e. waste water, exhaust duct) for the purpose of heating potable water. This includes but is not limited to drain water, wash compartment, and/or exhaust heat exchangers; and supplemental heat pumps. The equipment:
1) must use a minimum of 95% of water volume from the cold-water inlet for the wash and rinse cycle. The machine can have both cold-water and hot-water inlets, but a maximum of 5% of wash rinse cycle water shall come from the hot water; 
2) must have an inlet water temperature of 70 ± 3°F; and 
3) must operate at or above 180°F. "

Metric that represents total washing energy, including any internal or external booster heater energy in addition to the tank, heat, motor, control, and any additional auxiliary energy, expressed in kWh/rack.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The racks per hour for this dishwasher.
If the dishwasher claims the hot water energy offset, this represents the hot water energy offset in kWh/rack, calculated with Equation 1 of the Specification.

Metric that represents total washing energy, including any internal or external booster heater energy in addition to the tank, heat, motor, control, and any additional auxiliary energy, expressed in kWh/rack.

The idle energy rate is the rate of energy consumed by the dishwasher while “holding” or maintaining wash tank water at the thermostat(s) set point.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

The SNIA Taxonomy is a categorization scheme for use in segmenting the data center storage market by end-use application and key product characteristics.  The three categories eligible for ENERGY STAR certification are Online 2, Online 3, and Online 4.

A storage controller can be implemented in two different ways.  Scale-up storage is a storage product comprised of a discreet storage controller (with or without redundancy), which has a full view of all the storage devices in the storage product. Incremental storage capacity is added by the addition of storage devices under the control of the existing storage controller.  While Scale-out storage is a storage product capable of being comprised of two or more discreet storage controllers (with or without redundancy), combined with an overall integration or aggregation function resulting in a single storage product view for attached servers. Each discreet storage controller often has a partial view to a partition of the overall system's storage devices, but this is not a fixed requirement. Incremental storage capacity is added by the addition of storage devices under the control of the existing storage controller(s) and/or addition of additional storage devices along with additional controller(s).

A configuration provided by the manufacturer may be optimized for the following workload types: transaction, streaming, or capacity.  Transaction is a workload type optimized for random I/O usage measured in I/O per second per watt.  Streaming is a workload type optimized primarily for sequential I/O usage, measured in MiB per second per watt.  Capacity is a workload type optimized for maximum storage as measured by GB (Raw Capacity) per watt.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Residential Dishwashers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 7.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Residential Dishwashers that are effective as of July 19, 2023. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/appliances/dishwashers/key_product_criteria
columns_name: Capacity - Maximum Number of Place Settings
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2024 Criteria
columns_description: An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the dishwasher under typical conditions, including the machine energy used by the dishwasher during a dishwashing cycle, any additional energy used by a water heater to heat the water, and the energy used by the dishwasher while in standby mode. It is based on an annual usage of 215 loads per year, or around 4 per week, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix C. Actual energy consumption will vary depending on your usage patterns, including how often you run the dishwasher and what cycle you select.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Product depth when the door is shut and not including the handle.

Type refers to whether the product is considered a standard-sized dishwasher or a compact-sized dishwasher. Standard-sized models can fit at least eight place settings and six serving pieces. Products that cannot fit those amounts are considered compact-sized models.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.

Indicates whether the model meets optional connected criteria as defined in the specification, which may include functions helpful to the electrical grid (standardized signals and responses to manage energy use) and those helpful to consumers, such as scheduling and energy reporting.
How much less energy the unit uses per year relative to the U.S. Federal standard, expressed as a percent.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The mandatory water efficiency standards for residential dishwashers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and U.S. federal laws.
Tub material(s) could be stainless steel, plastic, hybrid, or other.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Drying method(s) applicable to the dishwasher may include air dry, condensation dry, fan-assisted dry, heated dry, mineral dry, and/or automatic door release.
The maximum number of place settings as recommended by the manufacturer.
Product width.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
A soil-sensing dishwasher  means a dishwasher that has the ability to adjust any energy-consuming aspect of the normal cycle based on the soil load of the dishes.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
The mandatory energy standards for residential dishwashers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and U.S. federal laws.
Indicates which standardized protocol is used to send load management messages to the unit.
The Hardware Architecture describes the type of module/device within or external to the system needed for connection.
Features applicable to the dishwasher may include hard food filter, self-cleaning filter, cycle status lights, 3rd rack, top controls, and/or front controls.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

This is the estimated per cycle water use of the dishwasher under typical conditions, expressed as the number of gallons of water delivered to the machine during one cycle, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Subpart B, Section 430, Appendix C. Actual water consumption will vary depending on the settings chosen.
How much less water the unit uses per cycle relative to the U.S. Federal standard, expressed as a percent.
