Whether or not the manufacturer offers a warranty for this product.
The material used for the window (generally glass, coated glass, or plastic).

The rate of air passing through the storm window when mounted over a calibrated panel, expressed in cubic feet per minute per square foot (cfm/ft2). Lower air leakage ratings mean that less air passes through the storm window.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
The ability of the storm window to reflect heat inside instead of emitting outside. Emissivity ranges from 0 to 1, with a lower value reflecting more heat and being more efficient.
Whether or not weather stripping is included with this product.
Is a screen included in the standard version of this storm window model?

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
How the window opens and closes.

The amount of solar energy (heat) that passes through the storm window. Solar transmittance ranges from 0 to 1. Generally, higher solar transmittance values are preferable in colder climates and lower values are preferable in warmer climates.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The storm window's moisture management system. Please note, a moisture management system is not required for ENERGY STAR certified interior storm windows.
The number of tracks of the storm window.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

The storm window is only considered ENERGY STAR certified when installed in this climate zone. Climate zones share general climatic conditions, such as the number of heating days and cooling days, and are indicated by a shaded area on the ENERGY STAR storm window label.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Displays
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 8.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Displays that came into effect on January 28, 2020. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at: https://www.energystar.gov/products/office_equipment/displays/displays_key_product_criteria

columns_description: Features enabled in the default tested Sleep Mode.
Available methods of delivering power to the display.
The 2 types of Displays eligible for ENERGY STAR certification are: Computer Monitors and Signage Displays.
A color space is a defined range of colors. Well known color spaces include sRGB, AdobeRGB and DCI-P3. Color spaces listed here are fully supported (100% of the defined range) by the Display.
The fixed physical pixel count of the display.
Does the model tested include a USB Type C port with Power Delivery capability?
The fixed physical pixel count of the display.
The number of Signage Display panels in the Maximum Tiled Configuration.
The diagonal screen size in inches.

The maximum Sleep Mode power requirement for a Signage Display model with the particular features to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Power Consumption in Sleep Mode cannot exceed this value. Computer Monitors must meet Total Energy Consumption requirements.
Features enabled in the default tested On Mode.

The HDR performance level for models that meet the VESA DisplayHDR CTS v1.0 Section 5.1 criteria. The model must meet the HDR performance level for all three white luminance criteria, including the 10% Center Patch Minimum Requirement (cd/m2), Full-screen Flash Minimum Requirement (cd/m2), and Full-screen Long-duration Minimum Requirement (cd/m2). N/A if the model does not meet the VESA DisplayHDR criteria.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
The most common screen types include TN LCD, IPS LCD, VA LCD, OLED, and Plasma.

The maximum On Mode power requirement for a Signage Display model with the given Screen Area and Maximum Reported Luminance to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Power Consumption in On Mode cannot exceed this value. Computer Monitors must meet Total Energy Consumption requirements.
The visible area of the Display that produces images.
For ABC-enabled displays, this is the on-mode power drawn by the display in a room with bright ambient light.

The power mode in which the product is connected to a power source, and is not providing any On Mode or Sleep Mode functions. This mode may persist for an indefinite time. The product may only exit this mode by direct user actuation of a power switch or control. Some products may not have this mode.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

This calculation (for Computer Monitors only) assumes a daily duty cycle of 35% in On Mode and 65% hours in Sleep Mode over the course of a year. Signage Displays must meet On Mode, Sleep Mode, and Off Mode power requirements.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

The power mode the product enters after receiving a signal from a connected device or an internal stimulus. The product may also enter this mode by virtue of a signal produced by user input. The product must wake on receiving a signal from a connected device, a network, a remote control, and/or an internal stimulus. While the product is in this mode, it is not producing a visible picture, with the possible exception of user-oriented or protective functions such as product information or status displays, or sensor-based functions.

The maximum Total Energy Consumption requirement for a Computer Monitor model with the given Screen Area and Resolution to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Total Energy Consumption cannot exceed this value. Signage Displays must meet On Mode, Sleep Mode, and Off Mode power requirements.
The rated or reported maximum power which the model can deliver via USB-C connection (W).

The photometric measure of the luminous intensity per unit area of light travelling in a given direction, expressed in candelas per square meter (cd/m^2). Luminance refers to the brightness settings of a display.
Is the Signage Display model tested as a Tiled Display System?
The range of color supported within the CIE LUV 1976 u' v' color space and calculated per Section 5.18 Gamut Area of the Information Display Measurements Standard Version 1.03.
Display contrast ratio at 0 degrees from the perpendicular, expressed as a integer relative to 1 (e.g., 1000 means 1000:1).
Display contrast ratio at +85 degrees from the perpendicular, expressed as a integer relative to 1 (e.g., 1000 means 1000:1).
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Display contrast ratio at -85 degrees from the perpendicular, expressed as a integer relative to 1 (e.g., 1000 means 1000:1).

A computer monitor that has all of the following features and functionalities: (a) A contrast ratio of at least 60:1 measured at a horizontal viewing angle of at least 85° from the perpendicular on a flat screen or 83° on a curved screen, with or without a screen cover glass; (b) A native resolution greater than or equal to 2.3 megapixels (MP); and, (c) A color gamut 32.9% of CIE LUV.
Additional features and networking options available on the display.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Available methods of delivering content to the display.
For ABC-enabled displays, this is the on-mode power consumed by the display in a room with low ambient light.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

The power mode in which the product has been activated, and is providing one or more of its principal functions. The common terms "active," "in-use," and "normal operation" also describe this mode. The power in this mode is typically greater than the power in Sleep Mode and Off Mode.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

columns_description:
The Jacobi Successive Over-relaxation (SOR) workload implements a transaction that exercises typical access
patterns in finite difference applications. Indicate the SOR workload efficiency score for this configuration.
The SERT Active State Efficiency Score as defined in ENERGY STAR Computer Servers V3, Equation 3.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

An Auxiliary Processing Accelerator (APA) are computing expansion add-in cards installed in general-purpose add-in expansion slots.  The model name of APA #2 is listed if it is included in this configuration.

An Auxiliary Processing Accelerator (APA) are computing expansion add-in cards installed in general-purpose add-in expansion slots.  The model name of APA #3 is listed if it is included in this configuration.

If Yes, this submission represents a single server.  If No, this submission represents a product family which is a high-level description referring to a group of computers sharing on chassis/motherboard combination that often contains hundreds of possible hardware and software configuration.

A computer server with greater storage capacity than a standard computer server. As shipped, these computer servers support 30 or more storage devices. These servers differ from Storage Products in that they run computer server operating systems and software stacks.
The memory capacity per dual in-line memory module, measured in GB, for this configuration.

Types of power saving features available include dynamic voltage and frequency of scaling of processor(s), processor or core reduced power states, power capping, variable speed fan control based on power or thermal readings, low power memory states, and lower power I/O states.
If liquid cooling capability is enabled in hardware upon shipment.
If liquid cooling capability requires the end user to enable it.

Sorting is one of the most common and important operations in computing. The SORT worklet sorts a randomized 64-bit integer array during each transaction. Indicate the SORT workload efficiency score for this configuration.
The manufacturer reported total normalized performance component (numerator) used to calculate the configuration’s Active State Efficiency Score.

The Storage-Workload has four different transactions, two random and two sequential transaction-pairs. Each pair
has a write and a read transaction. Indicate the Random workload efficiency score for this configuration.
If Other Power Saving Feature 3 requires the end user to enable it.
The brand of the processor(s) installed in the product.
The number of processors installed in the product's as-shipped configuration.
The manufacturer reported idle power value.

The model or configuration number for the typical or single configuration of the qualified product family. It is defined as a product configuration that lies between the Minimum and Maximum Power configurations and is representative of a deployed product with high volume sales.
The central processing unit package may include one or more processor cores.
SSJ is a simulated Online Transaction Processing (OLTP) workload, and represents a Server Side Java application. Indicate the SSJ workload efficiency score for this configuration.
The central processing unit package may include one or more processor cores.
The model name of the processor(s) installed in the product.
The model name of the processor(s) installed in the product.
If storage power management is enabled in hardware upon shipment.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The product of the current and voltage of the circuit at the maximum load the power supply is designed to support.
The SERT Active State Efficiency Score as defined in ENERGY STAR Computer Servers V3, Equation 3.
The central processing unit package may include one or more processor cores.

The number of buffered double data rate (DDR) channels per Server/Blade/Node available in the configuration.  A buffered DDR channel is defined as a channel or Memory Port connecting a Memory Controller to a defined number of memory devices (e.g. DIMMs) in a computer server. A typical computer server may contain multiple Memory Controllers, which may in turn support one or more Buffered DDR Channels. As such, each Buffered DDR Channel serves only a fraction of the total addressable memory space in a computer server.
The number of dual in-line memory module installed in the product's  configurations.
The number of solid state drives (SSDs) in this configuration.  A SSD is defined as a storage device that uses memory chips instead of rotating magnetic platters for data storage.
The number of rotational drives in this configuration.  A rotational drive is defined as a computer storage device which reads and writes to one or more rotating magnetic disk platters.

A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that converts ac  input power to one or more dc power outputs for the purpose of powering a computer server. A computer server PSU must be self-contained and physically separable from the motherboard and must connect to the system via a removable or hard-wired electrical connection. A power supply unit can be installed explicitly for power redundancy in this configuration.

Memory scaling in Capacity is done through a scheme known as input data caching (IDC). Indicate the Capacity workload efficiency score for this configuration. These values reflect the updated SERT Version 1.1.0.

The Storage-Workload has four different transactions, two random and two sequential transaction-pairs. Each pair
has a write and a read transaction. Indicate the Sequential workload efficiency score for this configuration.
See ENERGY STAR Computer Servers V3.0, Section G.2, for definition of low-end Performance Configuration.
If processor dynamic voltage scaling capability requires the end user to enable it.
A measure of the rate at which the processor executes operations in GHz for the configuration.
The memory capacity per dual in-line memory module, measured in GB, for this configuration.

The power supply type can be either Single-output or Multi-output. A single-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Single-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs shall be no greater than 20 watts. A multi-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to more than one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Multi-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs is greater than or equal to 20 watts
The product of the current and voltage of the circuit at the maximum load the power supply is designed to support.
The CryptoAES workload implements a transaction that encrypts and decrypts data. Indicate the CryptoAES workload efficiency score for this configuration.

The Jacobi Successive Over-relaxation (SOR) workload implements a transaction that exercises typical access
patterns in finite difference applications. Indicate the SOR workload efficiency score for this configuration.

Hashing and encryption/decryption are two pillars of modern computer security. The SHA-256 workload utilizes standard Java functions to perform SHA-256 transformations on a byte array. Indicate the SHA256 workload efficiency score for this configuration.

The Storage-Workload has four different transactions, two random and two sequential transaction-pairs. Each pair
has a write and a read transaction. Indicate the Random workload efficiency score for this configuration.
SSJ is a simulated Online Transaction Processing (OLTP) workload, and represents a Server Side Java application. Indicate the SSJ workload efficiency score for this configuration.
The number of expansion slots available for Input/Output (I/O) Devices and/or Auxiliary Processing Accelerators (APAs).
If processor power management is enabled in hardware upon shipment.
The model name of the processor(s) installed in the product.
The latest EPA approved SERT version used during testing.
The speed of the memory, measured in GHz, for this configuration.

The power supply type can be either Single-output or Multi-output. A single-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Single-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs shall be no greater than 20 watts. A multi-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to more than one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Multi-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs is greater than or equal to 20 watts.
The product of the current and voltage of the circuit at the maximum load the power supply is designed to support.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

The model or configuration number for the high-end performance configuration of the qualified product family. It is defined as the combination of Processor Socket Power, PSUs, Memory, Storage (HDD/SDD), and I/O devices that represents either the higher-price or higher-performance computing platform within the Product Family.
The brand of the processor(s) installed in the product.

A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that converts ac  input power to one or more dc power outputs for the purpose of powering a computer server. A computer server PSU must be self-contained and physically separable from the motherboard and must connect to the system via a removable or hard-wired electrical connection. A power supply unit can be installed explicitly for power redundancy in this configuration.
The brand of the processor(s) installed in the product.

A computer server designed with extensive Reliability, Availability, Serviceability (RAS) and scalability features integrated in the micro architecture of the system, CPU, and chipset.  See Appendix B of the Version 2.0 Computer Servers Program Requirements for more details on the definition of a Resilient System.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
A thread is the smallest sequence of instructions managed by an operating system.
The number of blade slots populated on the chassis, for this configuration.
The types of power saving features that require the end user to enable them.
The Compress workload implements a transaction that compresses and decompresses data. Indicate the Compress workload efficiency score for this configuration.
The LU workload implements a transaction that computes the LU factorization of a dense matrix using partial pivoting. Indicate the LU workload efficiency score for this configuration.
The manufacturer reported idle power value.
The number of solid state drives (SSDs) in this configuration.  A SSD is defined as a storage device that uses memory chips instead of rotating magnetic platters for data storage.
The number of solid state drives (SSDs) in this configuration.  A SSD is defined as a storage device that uses memory chips instead of rotating magnetic platters for data storage.
The number of power supply units that are installed in this configuration.
The Compress workload implements a transaction that compresses and decompresses data. Indicate the Compress workload efficiency score for this configuration.
The LU workload implements a transaction that computes the LU factorization of a dense matrix using partial pivoting. Indicate the LU workload efficiency score for this configuration.
If processor dynamic frequency scaling capability is enabled in hardware upon shipment.
If low power memory states require the end user to enable them.
The number of processors installed in the product's as-shipped configuration.
If low power I/O states are enabled in hardware upon shipment.

Hashing and encryption/decryption are two pillars of modern computer security. The SHA-256 workload utilizes standard Java functions to perform SHA-256 transformations on a byte array. Indicate the SHA256 workload efficiency score for this configuration.
If processor or core reduced power states require the end user to enable them.
The number of rotational drives in this configuration.  A rotational drive is defined as a computer storage device which reads and writes to one or more rotating magnetic disk platters.

The Flood workload is based upon STREAM, a popular benchmark that measures memory bandwidth across four common and important array operations. Indicate the Flood workload efficiency score for this configuration. These values reflect the updated SERT Version 1.1.0.
A thread is the smallest sequence of instructions managed by an operating system.
A measure of the rate at which the processor executes operations in GHz for the configuration.

The number of buffered double data rate (DDR) channels per Server/Blade/Node available in the configuration.  A buffered DDR channel is defined as a channel or Memory Port connecting a Memory Controller to a defined number of memory devices (e.g. DIMMs) in a computer server. A typical computer server may contain multiple Memory Controllers, which may in turn support one or more Buffered DDR Channels. As such, each Buffered DDR Channel serves only a fraction of the total addressable memory space in a computer server.
The installed amount of dynamic random-access memory the system can support, measured in GB.
The installed amount of dynamic random-access memory the system can support, measured in GB.

A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that converts ac  input power to one or more dc power outputs for the purpose of powering a computer server. A computer server PSU must be self-contained and physically separable from the motherboard and must connect to the system via a removable or hard-wired electrical connection. A power supply unit can be installed explicitly for power redundancy in this configuration.
The memory capacity per dual in-line memory module, measured in GB, for this configuration.
If I/O power management is enabled in hardware upon shipment.

The power supply type can be either Single-output or Multi-output. A single-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Single-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs shall be no greater than 20 watts. A multi-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to more than one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Multi-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs is greater than or equal to 20 watts.
The Compress workload implements a transaction that compresses and decompresses data. Indicate the Compress workload efficiency score for this configuration.
The CryptoAES workload implements a transaction that encrypts and decrypts data. Indicate the CryptoAES workload efficiency score for this configuration.

patterns in finite difference applications. Indicate the SOR workload efficiency score for this configuration.

The number of buffered double data rate (DDR) channels per Server/Blade/Node available in the configuration.  A buffered DDR channel is defined as a channel or Memory Port connecting a Memory Controller to a defined number of memory devices (e.g. DIMMs) in a computer server. A typical computer server may contain multiple Memory Controllers, which may in turn support one or more Buffered DDR Channels. As such, each Buffered DDR Channel serves only a fraction of the total addressable memory space in a computer server.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Water Coolers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Water Coolers that are effective March 23, 2022 . A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/other/water_coolers#specs
columns_name: Daily Energy Use (On Mode With No Water Draw) (kWh/day)
On Mode Performance for Cold Water Draw
On Mode Performance for Hot Water Draw
columns_description: The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
The amount of cold water a product can deliver at the required temperature, in gallons per hour.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The required energy to maintain cold and/or hot water at appropriate dispensing temperatures for one day. This does not account for energy consumed after water has been withdrawn.

"The source of water for the water cooler.  Bottled: A bottle or reservoir supplies water to the water cooler. The bottle may be either top loading, or bottom loading (typically contained within the base of the unit). Point of Use Tap water is supplied to the water cooler through a pressurized water source. Conversion-type: The water cooler can be supplied by either a bottle or tap water."
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The amount of hot water a product can deliver at the required temperature, in number of exact 6 ounce cups per hour.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Water temperature from the on mode with no water draw portion of the test.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP)
A performance metric for efficiency of a product after cold water has been withdrawn. Higher OMP signifies higher efficiency.
A performance metric for efficiency of a product after hot water has been withdrawn. Higher OMP signifies higher efficiency.

"Cold Only Units: These units dispense cold water only.  Cook and Cold Units: These units dispense both cold and room-temperature water.  Hot and Cold Units: These units dispense both hot and cold water.  Hot, Cook, and Cold Units: These units dispense hot, cold, and room temperature water."

"High Capacity coolers offer a greater volume of hot and cold water per hour, but use more energy. These products are appropriate for high-traffic spaces, like an office or commercial space.  Low Capacity water coolers offer greater energy savings, but produce less cold and hot water per hour. These products are a good choice for a home or other low-use application."
Some ENERGY STAR water coolers offer sparkling, flavored, or alkaline water in addition to cold water.

For conditioned storage water coolers, thermally conditioned water is stored in a tank in the water cooler and is available instantaneously. For on demand water coolers, water is heated as it is requested, which saves energy, but typically takes a few minutes to deliver.
Additional features may include connected capability, energy saving modes, or touchless dispensing.

columns_name: Professional Imaging Product Ready Mode Power (W)
columns_description: The average power of the DFE recorded while the main Imaging Equipment product is in Sleep Mode, applicable to DFEs with network-capable Sleep Modes.
Whether the product's output is monochrome (shades of black and white) or color.
The maximum claimed monochrome (black and white) speed in ipm (images per minute) and mppm (mail pieces per minute) when processing the given media.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
A performance metric that indicates the energy required by a  Professional Imaging Product to produce an image once in its Production Mode. A lower number translates to a higher efficiency.
The power required by a Professional Imaging Product to maintain its Ready Mode.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

Whether or not a copier, fax machine, MFD, or printer has the capability to produce images on both sides of an output sheet, without manual manipulation of output as an intermediate step. 

A product is considered to have automatic duplexing capability only if all accessories needed to produce duplex output are included with the product upon shipment.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

Typical electricity consumption (measured in kilowatt-hours) during normal operation over a specified period of time. Typical Electricity Consumption (TEC) is a method of testing and comparing the energy performance of certain imaging equipment products and focuses on the typical electricity consumed by a product while in normal operation during a representative period of time. The TEC metric is a proxy for a typical weekly electricity consumption. Please note: the TEC value should be used as a way to compare products' energy consumption values under a set duty cycle and operating conditions. Actual energy consumption will differ, based on how the product is used. TEC is not applicable to all imaging equipment products.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The power measured when a product enters Sleep Mode, either automatically after a period of inactivity, in response to user manual action, or in response to external electrical stimulus.
The average power of the DFE recorded while the main Imaging Equipment product is in Ready State.
Annualized TEC of the DFE.

The DFE Typical Electricity Consumption (TECDFE) metric assumes 9 hours in Ready State five days a week and the remainder in Sleep Mode. DFEs without a Sleep Mode are assumed to be in Ready State 168 hours per week.
The model number of the DFE. Again, the model number may be the same as or different from that of the Imaging Equipment product.

A DFE is functionally-integrated server that hosts other computers and applications and acts as an interface to Imaging Equipment. A DFE provides greater functionality to the Imaging Equipment. A DFE offers three or more of the following advanced features: network connectivity in various environments; mailbox functionality; job queue management; machine management (e.g., waking the Imaging Equipment from a reduced power state); advanced graphic user-interface (UI); ability to initiate communication with other host servers and client computers (e.g., scanning to email, polling remote mailboxes for jobs); or ability to post-process pages (e.g., reformatting pages prior to printing). 

The manufacturer may be the same as or different from that of the Imaging Equipment product.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product with the measurement taken 15 minutes after the start of a previous job.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product, with the measurement taken after the product has been powered on and has indicated it is in Ready State.
The time set by the manufacturer prior to shipping that determines when the product will enter a lower-power Mode (e.g., Sleep, Auto-off) following completion of its primary function.
The power measured when the product has been manually or automatically switched off but is still plugged in and connected to the mains.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product, with the measurement taken after the product has been in Sleep Mode for 1 hour.

characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
Eligible product type include: printer, scanner, copier, fax machine, multifunction device (MFD), digital duplicator, or mailing machine.

A functional adder is a data and network interface or other feature that adds functionality to the marking engine of an imaging equipment product and provides a power allowance when qualifying products according to the OM method.
Indicates whether the product is a Professional Imaging Product.
Required for all submissions which contain remanufactured products. Indicate if the certified product or product family includes remanufactured products.

1) Large Format: Products designed for A2 media and larger, including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media greater than or equal to 406 mm wide. Large-format products may also be capable of printing on standard-size or small-format media. 2) Standard Format: Products designed for standard-sized media (e.g., Letter, Legal, Ledger, A3, A4, B4), including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media between 210 mm and 406 mm wide. Standard-size products may also be capable of printing on small-format media. 3) Small Format: Products designed for media sizes smaller than those defined as Standard (e.g., A6, 4”x6”, microfilm), including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media less than 210 mm wide.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The marking technology of the product: direct thermal, dye sublimation, electro-photographic, impact, ink jet, high performance ink jet, solid ink, stencil, thermal transfer.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Residential Clothes Dryers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 1.1 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Clothes Dryers that are effective as of January 1, 2015. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at: https://www.energystar.gov/products/appliances/clothes_dryers/key_product_criteria
columns_name: Paired ENERGY STAR Clothes Washer Available
Calculated Combined Energy Factor - Max Dryness Setting (lbs/kWh)
Paired ENERGY STAR Clothes Washer ENERGY STAR Model Identifier
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2024 Criteria
columns_description: This field is used to indicate the fuel type used to heat the air necessary to dry the clothes, either electric or gas.
Indicates if the clothes dryer is part of a laundry center.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.

Highly energy efficient heat pump technology typically heats, dehumidifies and circulates air in the dryer drum, so no vent is required. A Heat Pump model solely uses heat pump technology to dry clothes, while a Hybrid Heat Pump model uses a combination of heat pump technology and traditional electric resistance heating technology.
Indicates if the clothes dryer is being marketed as a matched pair with an ENERGY STAR Clothes Washer.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

Features applicable to the clothes dryer may include drum light, wrinkle prevention option, steam cycle, sanitization cycle, filter cleaning indicator, energy monitor/indicator, time remaining display, and supplementary drying system.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.

The Calculated CEF – Max Dry is a measure of the dryer’s energy performance in a more energy consumptive setting, namely the normal cycle with the highest dryness setting as defined in the ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2017 criteria. The Calculated CEF – Max Dry should not be directly compared to the CEF field, which is tested using the medium dryness setting, and represents a rated rather than measured value. The CEF metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Heat pump dryers require refrigerants as well. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower GWP alternative refrigerant options for clothes dryers include R-290.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the dryer is done or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Clothes dryers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
Paired clothes washer ENERGY STAR Model Identifier .

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
Indicates the type of refrigerant used in the model.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

The estimated annual energy use is based on the Combined Energy Factor and an annual usage of 283 cycles per year, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2. Actual energy consumption will vary on your usage patterns, including how often your run the dryer, what cycle you select, and load size. NOTE: For gas dryers the estimated annual energy use is expressed in kilowatt hours to allow for comparison, and represents the equivalent multi-source energy use of the product (e.g., natural gas or propane typically expressed in British thermal units (Btu)).
The depth of the clothes dryer.
Open Standard - Application Layer include SEP 1.x, SEP2.x, OpenADR, etc.
The height of the clothes dryer.
The width of the clothes dryer.

Venting Configuration refers to how the clothes dryer exhausts heated air. Vented clothes dryers exhaust the evaporated moisture from the clothes dryer cabinet using a vent which typically leads to a building’s exterior. Ventless clothes dryers use a closed loop system with an internal condenser to remove the evaporated moisture from the heated air. Moisture is discharged from the cabinet and instead collected in a reservoir or drained through a tube.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

This is the drum capacity of the clothes dryers in cubic feet as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2. Products with a drum capacity less than 4.4 cubic feet are considered compact.

CEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR clothes dryers; the higher the CEF the more efficient the clothes dryer. The metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).

The estimated energy test cycle time is the time taken to complete the test cycle necessary for ENERGY STAR certification. Products must complete the energy test cycle in less than 80 minutes in order to be certified as ENERGY STAR. The estimated test cycle time does not reflect actual consumer cycle times which vary as a result of load size, dampness, and composition.

The cycle selection and settings (temperature and dryness where separately selectable) as defined in the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2, Section 3.3, used for certification to ENERGY STAR.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

Provide the manufacturer reported Daily Energy Consumption values, which will appear on the ENERGY STAR list of qualified products. The directive (#2011-05) on Measured versus Reported Values for ENERGY STAR Certification addresses the instance where reported DECs may differ from measured DECs.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Light Fixtures
resource.description: Please note, as of January 5, Ceiling Fan Light Kits are no longer included in this dataset. The Ceiling Fan Light Kit dataset can be found here: https://data.energystar.gov/Active-Specifications/ENERGY-STAR-Certified-Ceiling-Fans-Light-Kit/3zeh-haeu/data. Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 2.0, 2.1, or 2.2 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Luminaires. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?fuseaction=find_a_product.showProductGroup&pgw_code=LU#specs.
columns_name: Energy Efficiency - Measured Outside the Fixture (lumens/Watt)
Energy Efficiency - Measured at the Source (lumens/Watt)
columns_description: The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Light sources can be fully integrated into a light kit or removable by a consumer by custom connectors, wire nuts, pronged plugs like GU10, GU24 or sockets e.g. E26 known as the Edison base.

A description of the "color" of a light source measured on the Kelvin (K) scale. CFLs are available in a range of color temperatures. Lower values (2700-3000K) mean the white light has a warmer (red-yellow) tone, while higher kelvin (4100-6500K) mean the white light has a cooler (bluer) tone.

Most fixtures are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some fixtures have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers, three-way, or photo cell controls. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product. For light fixtures shipped with ENERGY STAR bulbs, the special features may apply to either the bulb or fixture.

The R9 value is not included in the Color Rendering Index (CRI) score but important for a light source to show red in objects with red in them, such as skin tones, natural wood tones, produce, meats, and artwork. Higher numbers represent more accurate rendering of red.
The light source technology utilized by the fixture: compact fluorescent light (CFL), light emitting diode (LED), or halogen.
Total power consumed by the luminaire while in use.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Indicates if the lamp manufacturer claims that the lamp is dimmable and meets the requirements in the specification.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The aperture size in inches for recessed downlight fixtures.
Indicates information on certification relevant to the consumer (i.e. product variations, unique issues concerning the model’s listing, etc.).

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
The ENERGY STAR Manufacturing Partner is the organization that has signed an ENERGY STAR Partnership Agreement and labels the model. This organization is typically the brand owner.

The Color Rendering Index (CRI) of a light source represents the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature. The ENERGY STAR specifications require a CRI of at least 80. Incandescent lighting has a CRI of 100. Early fluorescent lighting had CRIs in the 60s, resulting in unpleasant appearance of skin tones.

Measured outside the Fixture (lm/W): The quotient of the total luminous flux (lumens) emitted by the fixture over the total power input (Watts). It is expressed in lumens per watt (lm/W). For ENERGY STAR qualified fixtures this applies to light fixtures that are measured at the fixture level. This includes the following residential grade directional fixture types: line-voltage track lights, ceiling fan light kits, undercabinet and cove lighting, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface mounted and includes retrofit kits for existing recessed cans. This also includes the following LIMITED commercial fixture types: Accent lights such as line-voltage track lights, under cabinet task lights, portable desk task lights, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface-mounts BUT EXCLUDES typical commercial and industrial fixtures such as recessed troffers or linear forms (e.g. linear fluorescent pendants) typically used in office spaces.

The quotient of the total light source/lamp luminous flux (lumens) emitted over the total lamp power input (Watts). It is expressed in lm/W. For ENERGY STAR qualified fixtures this applies to light fixtures that are residential only, considered "non-directional" and have been measured at the light source level.

The amount of light emitted by the light source or light fixture. Non directional fixtures (with removable light sources i.e. GU24 base bulbs) are measured at the light source and do not account for light lost from the fixture, while other fixtures meant to put light on a specific application (e.g. recessed downlights, under cabinet lights, accent lights, cove lights) are measured at the fixture level, only counting the light that escapes the fixture.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

The expected useful life of the light source. Measured differently depending on the technology of the light source. For example, LED lighting expected useful life is based on the estimated point at which only 70% of the original light output remains, while for older technologies, like fluorescent and halogen, estimated useful life is based on the measured median sample life.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
For fixtures with removable light sources, the shape of the light source.
Indicates if a recessed downlight fixture is insulation contact (IC) rated or airtight.

The ratio of real power that flows to the light source versus the amount of power actually consumed.  A light fixture with a lower power factor will draw more current than a luminaire with a higher power factor for the same amount of power consumed.

The appearance of the light is indicated by the Correlated Color Temperature (CCT) on the Kelvin scale. Lower Kelvin numbers like 2700-3000K mean the light appears more “warm” like incandescent; a CCT of 3500-4100K mean the light is whiter and higher temperatures like 5000-6500K would appear slightly bluer. Light appearance is indicated on bulb packaging.

The ratio of the heat transferred to the water flowing through the water heater to the amount of energy consumed by the water heater.
Heat output refers to the useful heat transferred to the water, in thousand BTU per hour.
Height to vent is the distance from the bottom of the water heater's tank to its vent.
Tank height is the distance from the bottom of the water heater's tank to the top of its tank.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification

The date that the model is available for purchase.
The average hourly energy, expressed in Btu/hr, required to maintain the stored water temperature.
Input refers to the burner size of the gas-fired water heater, in thousand BTU per hour.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Vent size 2 is the width or diameter of a second vent opening.
The amount of water contained in the water heater measured in gallons. Some tankless water heaters do not have a storage volume.

All of these features are optional for ENERGY STAR Partners to report to EPA.
The four features include: Fault Detection and Display - the equipment reports, in plain text, system faults that have occurred; Performance Reporting - the equipment is capable of reporting at least three performance metrics such as fuel usage, hot water use, etc.; Energy Savings Reporting - the equipment is capable of analyzing performance to report potential energy savings opportunities to the user; Predictive Maintenance - the equipment is capable of tracking water heater use and wear rates to predict and alert the user of potential maintenance requirements.
Vent size is the width or diameter of the vent opening.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Fuel type refers to the kind of fuel that the water heater uses to heat the water, either natural gas or propane for gas-fired water heaters, or electric for heat pump water heaters.
This field is used to indicate the type of qualified product: Gas Storage Water Heater, Gas Storage-type Tankless Water Heater, Gas Tankless Water Heater, or Electric Heat Pump Water Heater.
Electric Input refers to the input wattage of the heat pump and ancillary electric components (e.g., fans, blowers, storage tank, piping, and controls).
Tank diameter is the width or diameter of the water heater’s tank.
